Question Text: Which of the following terms describe Ethernet addresses that can send one frame and is delivered to multiple devices on the LAN? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Broadcast address
b. Multicast address
c. IP address
d. MAC address
e. Unicast address
LLM Explanation: Broadcast and multicast addresses are used to send Ethernet frames to multiple devices on a LAN. A broadcast address (FF-FF-FF-FF-FF-FF) sends the frame to all devices, while a multicast address sends the frame to a specific group of devices that have subscribed to that multicast group. IP address, MAC address, and unicast address are used for sending frames to a single specific device on the LAN.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: ___________ is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision.
Choices:
a. CSMA/CD
b. CSMA/CA
c. TCP/IP
d. TCP/UDP
LLM Explanation: CSMA/CD, which stands for Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection, is a set of rules that determines how network devices respond when two devices send data at the same time, resulting in a collision. When a collision is detected, both devices stop transmitting, wait for a random time interval, and then retry to send the data again.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of LANs', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/ethernet/5857-csma-cd.html']

Question Text: Ethernet standard ___________ BASE-T defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling.
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet standard that defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling is 1000BASE-T. The '1000' in the standard name indicates the data rate of 1000 Mbps, which is equivalent to 1 Gbps (Gigabit per second). 10BASE-T and 100BASE-T are older Ethernet standards that support 10 Mbps and 100 Mbps respectively over UTP cabling, while 1BASE-T is not a valid Ethernet standard.

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Preamble field in the Ethernet header consists of a 56-bit pattern of alternating 1s and 0s that allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks to the incoming bit stream. The Start Frame Delimiter follows the Preamble and indicates the start of the Ethernet frame.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press)', 'IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Standard']

Question Text: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the ____________ IP address is in a different subnet than the host.
Choices:
a. Source
b. Destination
c. Unicast
d. Broadcast
LLM Explanation: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the destination IP address is in a different subnet than the host. When a host needs to communicate with another device on a different network, it forwards the packets to its default gateway, which then routes the packets to the appropriate destination network.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 16: IP Routing', 'Cisco Networking Academy: Introduction to Networks v7.0, Module 10: Network Layer']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Application TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol in the TCP/IP model. It is used for sending and receiving email messages between servers. TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and IP (Internet Protocol) reside in the transport and network layers, respectively, while Ethernet is a data link layer protocol.
URLs: ['Kurose, J. F., & Ross, K. W. (2017). Computer networking: a top-down approach. Pearson.', 'Tanenbaum, A. S., & Wetherall, D. (2011). Computer networks. Prentice Hall.']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Transport TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) resides in the Transport layer of the TCP/IP architecture. It provides reliable, connection-oriented data delivery between applications. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an Application layer protocol, Ethernet operates at the Data Link layer, and IP (Internet Protocol) functions at the Network layer.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th ed.). Pearson.', 'Odom, W. (2020). CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1. Cisco Press.', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13769-5.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: IP (Internet Protocol) resides in the Internet layer of the TCP/IP architecture. The Internet layer is responsible for addressing, packaging, and routing functions. It provides a way to transport packets from the source to the destination host across one or more IP networks. SMTP is an application layer protocol, TCP is a transport layer protocol, and Ethernet is a data link layer protocol in the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by Kevin R. Fall, W. Richard Stevens']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Data Link & Physical TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: Ethernet is a protocol that resides in the Data Link and Physical layers of the TCP/IP architecture. SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) is an application layer protocol, TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a transport layer protocol, and IP (Internet Protocol) is a network layer protocol.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by Kevin R. Fall, W. Richard Stevens']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols is used from PC1 to learn information from some other device on the same network?
Choices:
a. ping
b. ARP
c. DHCP
d. DNS
LLM Explanation: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) is used by a device to learn the MAC address associated with an IP address on the same network. When a device needs to communicate with another device on the local network, it sends an ARP request to resolve the IP address to the corresponding MAC address. The other protocols mentioned are not directly used for this purpose: ping tests reachability, DHCP assigns IP addresses, and DNS resolves domain names to IP addresses.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Wendell Odom, Chapter 12: IP Addressing and Subnetting', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/dynamic-address-allocation-resolution/13718-5.html']

Question Text: If the devices below were connected with UTP Ethernet cables, which pairs of devices would require a straight-through cable? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Router and PC
b. Switch and PC
c. Hub and switch
d. Router and hub
LLM Explanation: A straight-through Ethernet cable is used when connecting devices of different types, such as a host to a switch or a router to a PC. In the given choices, a router connected to a PC and a switch connected to a PC would require straight-through cables. Hubs and switches are considered similar devices, so they would use a crossover cable when directly connected to each other.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/switches/catalyst-6500-series-switches/21223-cable-connection-21223.html']

Question Text: Which of the following protocols are examples of TCP/IP data-link layer protocols? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. TCP
b. HTTP
c. Ethernet
d. PPP
e. SMTP
f. HTTPS
LLM Explanation: The data-link layer protocols in TCP/IP are responsible for delivering data over the physical network links. Ethernet and PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) are two examples of data-link layer protocols used in TCP/IP networks. Ethernet is commonly used in local area networks (LANs), while PPP is often used for point-to-point serial connections, such as dial-up or WAN links. TCP, HTTP, SMTP, and HTTPS are higher-layer protocols that operate at the transport layer (TCP) or application layer (HTTP, SMTP, HTTPS) of the TCP/IP model.
URLs: ['Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 3: Fundamentals of TCP/IP Transport and Applications', 'Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'Cisco CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 2, Chapter 15: Point-to-Point WANs']

Question Text: Which of the following statements are functions of a routing protocol? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Learning routes and putting those routes into the routing table for routes advertised to the router by its neighboring routers
b. Advertising known routes to neighboring routers
c. Learning routes for subnets directly connected to the router
d. Forwarding IP packets based on a packetâ€™s destination IP address
LLM Explanation: The main functions of a routing protocol are to learn routes from neighboring routers and advertise known routes to neighboring routers. The routing protocol takes the learned routes and puts them into the routing table. It does not learn routes for directly connected subnets, as those are learned via the interface configuration. Forwarding IP packets based on the destination IP is a function of the router itself, not the routing protocol.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom, Chapter 16: Routing Protocol Concepts and Configuration', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13769-5.html']

Question Text: When you open a web browser and type in the hostname www.examsdigest.com, your computer does not send an IP packet with a destination IP address www.examsdigest.com; it sends an IP packet to an IP address used by the web server for Examsdigest. TCP/IP needs a way to let a computer find the IP address used by the listed hostname. That method uses the Domain Name System (DNS).
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. When a user enters a hostname like www.examsdigest.com into a web browser, the computer does not directly send IP packets to that hostname. Instead, it first needs to resolve the hostname to the corresponding IP address used by the web server hosting the website. This process is handled by the Domain Name System (DNS). The computer sends a DNS query to a DNS server, which then returns the IP address associated with the requested hostname. Once the IP address is obtained, the computer can then send IP packets to that address to establish communication with the web server.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, by Wendell Odom', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross']

Question Text: A __________________ address is an address that enables transmission to every node in a local network.
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Multicast
c. Unicast
d. MAC
LLM Explanation: A broadcast address is used to transmit data to every node on a local network segment. It allows a single packet to be sent to all devices simultaneously. Broadcasts are limited to the local network and are not forwarded by routers.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html']

Question Text: TCP and ______________ are the two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols.
Choices:
a. UDP
b. HTTP
c. DNS
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP (User Datagram Protocol) are the two most commonly used transport layer protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite. TCP provides reliable, connection-oriented data delivery, while UDP provides unreliable, connectionless data delivery. HTTP, DNS, and SMTP are application layer protocols that rely on the transport layer protocols (TCP or UDP) for data transmission.
URLs: ['Kurose, J. F., & Ross, K. W. (2017). Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach (7th Edition). Pearson.', 'IETF RFC 793 - Transmission Control Protocol. (1981). https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc793', 'IETF RFC 768 - User Datagram Protocol. (1980). https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc768']

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The Frame Check Sequence (FCS) field in the Ethernet frame trailer provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine if the frame experienced transmission errors. The FCS contains a 4-byte CRC value calculated by the sending device. The receiving device recalculates the CRC and compares it to the value in the FCS field. If they match, the frame is considered error-free. If they differ, the frame is discarded due to transmission errors.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'IEEE 802.3-2018 - IEEE Standard for Ethernet']
